B. Configuring infrastructure as code

Configuring infrastructure as code (IaC) is the best approach for automating the provisioning of resources at the infrastructure layer without modifying application code. With IaC, you define and manage your infrastructure using code, which can be versioned and automated. This allows you to consistently and efficiently provision and manage resources, ensuring that the infrastructure is aligned with your application's requirements. IaC tools like Terraform and AWS CloudFormation are commonly used for this purpose.

Some orchestration systems allow for an approach called infrastructure-as-
code
(IaC). IaC
lets you use code to define the end state of your systems. For example, if you want to install
a particular version of an application on a fleet of VMs, you simply set the desired version
number, and the orchestration system figures out how to make it happen. Contrast this with
a more imperative approach such as scripting, where you would have to spell out the exact
steps to download and install the version of the application you want.

B. Snapshot all volumes attached to an instance.

In an IaaS (Infrastructure as a Service) platform, the first step a systems administrator would usually take to identify the scope of an incident is to snapshot all volumes attached to the affected instance. This action creates a copy of the instance's storage volumes at a specific point in time, preserving the state of the data, configurations, and potential evidence related to the incident.
